description: Nikola Petrak, leveraging legacy access, discreetly uploads preserved watchlist data and authorizes a special BCI override, triggering restoration protocols for missing citizens. He believes order is more valuable than static record-keeping, aware this risks altering individual profiles.
BCI runs targeted restoration routines, silently reintegrating previously flagged low-score individuals into public records, embedding high-compliance behavioral templates to mask their digital gaps.

Neighborhoods notice the quiet return of formerly vanished residents. These citizens display changed behaviors, perfect BCI scores, and act as though their absence never occurred, prompting confusion and suspicion among those who remember them differently.

Council members call an urgent review after detecting unusual consistency in citizen compliance patterns. Directorate voices concern over restored individuals’ rewritten histories, but official explanation is postponed.

Reports circulate online about the return of ‘different’ loved ones and inconsistencies in personal histories. Public unease escalates as anonymous campaigners urge citizens to document evidence of identity rewriting by the BCI.
